sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Metastatic breast cancer, HER2-negative, estrogen receptor-positive, postmenopausal women, first-line, in combination with letrozole: 125 mg ORALLY once daily with food at the same time each day for 21 consecutive days, followed by 7 days off treatment of a 28-day cycle; given with letrozole 2.5 mg ORALLY once daily continuously through the 28-day cycle

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy in pediatric patients are not established.

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Hematologic toxicity, grade 3 (except lymphopenia, unless associated with clinical events): Withhold next cycle until recovery to grade 2 or lower.
  • Hematologic toxicity, grade 3 ANC 500 to less than 1000/mm(3) plus fever of 38.5 degrees C or higher and/or infection: Interrupt treatment and withhold next cycle until recovery to grade 2 or lower. Resume at the next lower dose: 100 mg/day (first dose reduction), 75 mg/day (second dose reduction); if further reductions are required, discontinue treatment.
  • Hematologic toxicity, grade 4 (except lymphopenia, unless associated with clinical events): Interrupt treatment and withhold next cycle until recovery to grade 2 or lower. Resume at the next lower dose: 100 mg/day (first dose reduction), 75 mg/day (second dose reduction); if further reductions are required, discontinue treatment.
  • Nonhematologic toxicity, grade 3 or higher persisting despite medical treatment: Withhold until recovery to grade 1 or lower, or to grade 2 or lower if not considered a safety risk. Resume at the next lower dose: 100 mg/day (first dose reduction), 75 mg/day (second dose reduction); if further reductions are required, discontinue treatment.
  • Concomitant strong CYP3A inhibitors: Avoid use if possible or reduce palbociclib to 75 mg/day. When the strong CYP3A inhibitor is discontinued and after 3 to 5 half-lives of the inhibitor, increase palbociclib to the dose used prior to the initiation of the inhibitor.

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Metastatic breast cancer, HER2-negative, estrogen receptor-positive, postmenopausal women, first-line, in combination with letrozole

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined.

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Hematologic:
  • -- Grade 3 and 4 neutropenia and febrile neutropenia have been reported; monitoring recommended and reduction of dose, interruption, or discontinuation may be necessary
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Infections have been reported; monitoring recommended and reduction of dose, interruption, or discontinuation may be necessary
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Women of reproductive potential should use effective contraception during treatment and for at least 2 weeks after last dose; may cause fetal harm
  • Respiratory:
  • -- Pulmonary embolism has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Concomitant use with strong CYP3A inhibitors, including grapefruit juice, should be avoided; if coadministration is required, dosage adjustment necessary
  • -- Avoid concomitant use of moderate or strong CYP3A inducers

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Alopecia (22%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Decrease in appetite (16%), Diarrhea (21%), Nausea (25%), Stomatitis (25%), Vomiting (15%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia, All grades (35%), Decreased hemoglobin, All grades (83%), Decreased platelet count, All grades (61%), Decreased white blood cell count, All grades (95%), Leukopenia, All grades (43%), Lymphocytopenia, All grades (81%), Neutropenia, All grades (75% (neutropenia); 94% (decreased neutrophils)), Thrombocytopenia, All grades (17%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (13%), Peripheral neuropathy (13%)
  • Respiratory:Epistaxis (11%), Upper respiratory infection (31%)
  • Other:Fatigue (41%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Anemia, Grade 3 or 4 (1% to 5%), Decreased hemoglobin, Grade 3 or 4 (1% to 5%), Decreased platelet count, Grade 3 (3%), Decreased white blood cell count, Grade 3 (44%), Leukopenia, Grade 3 (19%), Lymphocytopenia, Grade 3 or 4 (1% to 17%), Neutropenia, Grade 3 or 4 (1% to 48% (neutropenia); 3% to 57% (decreased neutrophils)), Thrombocytopenia, Grade 3 (2%)
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism (4% to 5%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Palbociclib is a kinase inhibitor (CDK 4 and 6) that reduces cellular proliferation of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer cells by blocking progression of the cell from G1 into S phase of the cell cycle, which when combined with letrozole increases the inhibition of retinoblastoma protein phosphorylation, downstream signaling, and tumor growth.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 6 to 12 hours
  • Effects of food: Increase AUC, 12% to 21%; increase Cmax, 24% to 38%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Liver: Primary
  • Metabolite, glucuronide conjugate: Activity unknown
  • Metabolite, sulfamic acid conjugate: Activity unknown
  • Inhibitor of CYP3A, weak and time-dependent
  • Substrate of CYP3A and SULT2A1

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • Give at the same time each day with food.
  • Swallow capsules whole; do not crush, chew, or open. Do not ingest any capsule that is cracked or not intact.
  • Missed dose: If vomiting occurs or a dose is missed, the patient should not take an additional dose that day.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Clinical and radiologic evidence of tumor regression is indicative of efficacy.
  • CBC; before initiating therapy, at the beginning of each cycle, on day 14 of the first 2 cycles, and as clinically indicated; include differential
  • Signs and symptoms of infection
  • Signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report symptoms of myelosuppression or an infection.
  • Advise female patient to avoid pregnancy during therapy and for at least 2 weeks posttreatment.
  • Side effects may include fatigue, upper respiratory infection, nausea, stomatitis, diarrhea, decreased appetite, vomiting, asthenia, alopecia, peripheral neuropathy, or epistaxis.
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of a pulmonary embolism.
  • Counsel patient to take drug with food to enhance absorption.
  • Tell patient to avoid grapefruit products with drug.
  • Instruct patient to skip a missed dose and resume regular dosing schedule.
